objects.author: David Skinner
objects.title: COVID-19 outbreak reported in UofA student high rises
objects.html:
TUCSON (KVOA) - A COVID-19 outbreak has been detected through contact tracing according to a memo released by City of Tucson Council Member Steve Kozachik.

The Hub and Oliv high rises reported 86 positive cases since testing began right before the Labor Day Weekend.

Kozachik says testing has been conducted on students who live in the multiple high rise buildings that surround Main Gate Square.

Rescue Me Wellness tested students on August 28 and 29 as well as after the Labor Day weekend on September 8.

The percentage of positive tests (Hub-35% and Oliv-19%) rose in the second round of testing after the holiday.

Pima County is issuing orders to shut down the swimming pools at the high rises around the university.

The test Rescue Me Wellness is using is different than the one of the UA has implemented for its student body at large.

Some of the students tested reported false negative results from the rapid antigen test they took on the UA campus immediately prior to testing positive with the more accurate PCR protocol administered by Rescue Me Wellness.

"While on site doing the testing, we observed residents pack into Uber cars, heading out for the evening," said Kozachik. "Pizza deliveries were common. Community spread is clearly tied to the conditions within not only Hub Tucson, but other high rises in that area."

Kozachik is frustrated with how the owners of the two complexes is handling the situation.

He says CORE Spaces declined his request for the company to mandate 100% testing for all residents. The company cited restrictions in their leases to students.

The Ward 6 councilman believes UA can, and should exercise its leverage to compel testing by immediately issuing a directive that prevents any student from continuing to participate in any form of classroom instruction, including virtually, until they have produced a negative COVID-19 test result coming from a reliable PCR test.

Both the Hub and Oliv could come under a quarantine order if deemed necessary by the Pima County Health Department.

Copyright 2020 News 4 Tucson. All rights reserved.
objects.text:
TUCSON (KVOA) - A COVID-19 outbreak has been detected through contact tracing according to a memo released by City of Tucson Council Member Steve Kozachik.
The Hub and Oliv high rises reported 86 positive cases since testing began right before the Labor Day Weekend.
Kozachik says testing has been conducted on students who live in the multiple high rise buildings that surround Main Gate Square.
Rescue Me Wellness tested students on August 28 and 29 as well as after the Labor Day weekend on September 8.
The percentage of positive tests (Hub-35% and Oliv-19%) rose in the second round of testing after the holiday.
Pima County is issuing orders to shut down the swimming pools at the high rises around the university.
The test Rescue Me Wellness is using is different than the one of the UA has implemented for its student body at large.
Some of the students tested reported false negative results from the rapid antigen test they took on the UA campus immediately prior to testing positive with the more accurate PCR protocol administered by Rescue Me Wellness.
"While on site doing the testing, we observed residents pack into Uber cars, heading out for the evening," said Kozachik. "Pizza deliveries were common. Community spread is clearly tied to the conditions within not only Hub Tucson, but other high rises in that area."
Kozachik is frustrated with how the owners of the two complexes is handling the situation.
He says CORE Spaces declined his request for the company to mandate 100% testing for all residents. The company cited restrictions in their leases to students.
The Ward 6 councilman believes UA can, and should exercise its leverage to compel testing by immediately issuing a directive that prevents any student from continuing to participate in any form of classroom instruction, including virtually, until they have produced a negative COVID-19 test result coming from a reliable PCR test.
Both the Hub and Oliv could come under a quarantine order if deemed necessary by the Pima County Health Department.
